A. 

Overview 

Appendix 2 

27 

POWER SECTOR ASSESSMENT 

Pakistan’s power sector faces tremendous challenges: (i) generation capacity needs to 
1. 
be increased, (ii) constraints in the transmission and distribution systems have to be overcome, 
(iii)  financial  management  must  be  improved  and  the  sustainability  of  the  sector  entities 
assured, and (iv)  proper corporate governance structures for the successor companies have to 
be put in place.  
 
2. 
The Government of Pakistan has approved policies, strategies, and action plans for the 
power  sector  to  (i)  ensure  independent  regulation  of  the  power  sector;  (ii)  complete  the 
unbundling of the Water and Power Development Authority (WAPDA), establish four generation 
and  eight  distribution  companies,  and  the  National  Transmission  and  Despatch  Company 
(NTDC); (iii) commence the power sector privatization program; and (iv) evaluate and optimize 
the  fuel  sources  available  to  the  power  sector  to  ensure  energy  security  and  minimize  overall 
tariff requirements.  
 
3. 
The power sector will need to increase its capacity if the economic growth targets in the 
Medium-Term  Development  Framework,  2005–2010  (MTDF)  are  to  be  achieved  and  the 
poverty reduction strategy of the Government implemented. Currently, about 45% of Pakistan’s 
population has no access to electricity from the national grid. Existing bottlenecks in the power 
transmission  network  are  expected  to  result  in  significant  system  capacity  shortfalls,  which  in 
turn could restrict the GDP growth by almost 0.8% in fiscal year (FY) 2008. 
 
4. 
Transmission and distribution losses in the Pakistan power system amounted to 25% in 
2005.  In  the  transmission  system,  these  high  losses  are  caused  by  the  excess  load  on  the 
transmission lines and at substations. Total transmission losses are 7.5%, including secondary 
transmission system losses. Primary system losses are about 3.0%. The transmission system is 
aging,  overloaded,  and  poorly  maintained.  It  is  unreliable,  and  at  times  there  is  a  risk  of 
collapse. The system needs immediate rehabilitation, augmentation, and expansion to provide 
services  so  it  can  meet  consumer  demands  and  system  security  requirements.  The  safe  and 
reliable transmission of electricity remains a major challenge for Pakistan.  
 
B. 

Background  

1. 

Sector Policy 

5. 
In  2000,  the  Government  unveiled  the  “Vision  2025”  program  which  advocated 
accelerated  development  of  new  generation  facilities.  This  was  revised  in  2002,  with  greater 
reliance  placed  on  indigenous  fuel  sources—hydropower,  thermal  generation  using  local  coal 
reserves or local gas supplies, and renewable technologies. 
  
6. 
The  2002–2004  power  policy  includes  an  increase  in  power  generation  capacity  and 
encompasses  private,  public  and  private–public  models.  The  policy  continues  the  underlying 
theme of Vision 2025 by encouraging the use of indigenous resources, principally hydroelectric 
power and coal. A number of thermal and hydroelectric projects are currently being processed 
under the policy. 
 

 

 28 

Appendix 2 

2. 

Sector Strategy 

7. 
The  Government’s  strategy  for  the  power  sector  has  three  main  intended  outcomes: 
(i) sector  reforms  to  create  an  enabling  environment  for  private  sector  participation;  (ii) more 
capacity  building  in  all  sector  organizations,  including  financial  management,  efficiency 
improvement,  use  of  the  clean  development  mechanism,  and  project  management;  and 
(iii) completion  of  large  infrastructure  development  projects  in  generation,  transmission,  and 
distribution. 
 
8. 
The  MTDF  contains  a  medium-  and  long-term  integrated  national  energy  security  plan 
for the country. The objectives of the MTDF are (i) to increase power generation; (ii) to enhance 
the exploitation and production of oil, gas, and coal resources and to increase the share of coal 
and  alternative  energy  in  the  energy  mix;  (iii)  to  optimize  the  use  of  indigenous  sources  and 
reduce dependence upon imported sources; and (iv) to encourage and facilitate private sector 
involvement.  Table  A2.1  shows  how  the  MTDF  envisages  that  the  primary  energy  mix  will 
evolve  over  time.  The  strategy  for  bridging  the  energy  gap  assumes  that  gas  will  be  imported 
from  four  different  sources.  Two  gas  pipelines  are  planned  for  2015,  a  third  for  2020,  and  a 
fourth for 2030. Any remaining deficit will be met by oil imports. The resulting power generation 
plan  is  presented  in  Table  A2.2.  To  address  the  overloading  of  the  NTDC  network,  MTDF 
recommends the addition of four transmission lines and six grid stations to the 500 kV and 220 
kV systems.

9. 
The  MTDF  also  sets  out  an  investment  strategy  for  the  power  transmission  and 
distribution sectors. It recognizes that the existing transmission infrastructure and grid stations 
are  overloaded,  that  the  south–north  and  north–south  transmission  systems  need  to  be 
strengthened, and that new generation projects need to be connected to the national grid. The 
MTDF also address the problems of the distribution network, including overloaded substations 
and  high  distribution  losses,  and  recommends  that  the  network  be  expanded  and  efficiency 

 

 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

  

Appendix 2 

29 

improved.  The  MTDF  makes  other  recommendations,  among  them  to  (i)  ensure  independent 
regulation of the power sector, (ii) unbundle WAPDA and establish and fully operationalize the 
successor  companies,  and  (iii)  strengthen  the  privatization  program.  The  MTDF  also  specifies 
the  need  to  further  strengthen  the  regulatory  role  of  the  National  Electric  Power  Regulatory 
Authority (NEPRA).  
 

3. 

Major Stakeholders 

a. 

Ministry of Water and Power 

10. 
The Ministry of Water and Power (MOWP) is the federal government agency responsible 
for all policy matters related to the water and power sectors, and for overall supervision of the 
performance of organizations under its administrative control. In addition to its responsibility for 
policy,  MOWP  performs  certain  specific  functions,  such  as  carrying  out  strategic  and  financial 
planning  for  public  and  private  involvement  in  the  sector.  Proposals  for  power  sector  projects 
are scrutinized in MOWP, which assesses their technical and financial viability and adherence 
to  the  overall  strategic  plan.  Private  sector  projects  in  the  power  sector  are  processed  by  the 
Private  Power  Investment  Board  (PPIB),  supervised  by  MOWP,  which  establishes  policy 
guidelines  for  the  approval  of  private  projects.  Five-year  plans  and  annual  development 
programs in water and power sector are all overseen by MOWP. MOWP also monitors activities 
in power generation, transmission and distribution and performs a supervisory and advisory role 
in ensuring the smooth operation of the power sector.  
 

b. 

National Electric Power Regulatory Authority 

11. 
The  National  Electric  Power  Regulatory  Authority  (NEPRA)  was  established  by  the 
Regulation  of  Generation,  Transmission  and  Distribution  of  Electric  Power  Act,  1997  (Electric 
Power Act). It was created to introduce transparent and judicious economic regulation, based on 
sound  commercial  principles,  to  the  electric  power  sector.  It  performs  three  main  regulatory 
functions:  (i)  licensing  of  generation,  transmission  and  distribution  of  electric  power;  (ii)  tariff 
determination;  and  (iii)  setting  of  market  rules  and  operating  standards.  Over  the  last  5  years, 
NEPRA has established its regulatory credentials. ADB provided institutional capacity support to 
NEPRA in 2000 and 2001 through a technical assistance project.1 With regard to tariff setting, 
NEPRA  is  moving  toward  full  cost  recovery,  although  some  of  the  tariff  determinations  have 
favored consumers and have contributed to the poor financial performance of power companies 
and investors. NEPRA issues licenses to generation, transmission, and distribution companies, 
as  well  as  making  tariff  determinations.  Tariff  determinations  are  notified  by  the  Government 
and then become effective.  
 

c. 

Water and Power Development Authority  

The  Water  and  Power  Development  Authority  (WAPDA)  was  established  by  the  Water 
12. 
and  Power  Development  Authority  Act,  1958. 
include  generation, 
transmission  and  distribution  of  power,  along  with  additional  responsibilities  for  irrigation, 
drainage and flood control. It owns about 58% of the country’s total power generation capacity 
and  serves  over  13  million  customers,  representing  88%  of  all  the  electricity  customers  in  the 
country.  Between  1984  and  2005,  WAPDA’s  total  installed  power  generating  capacity

quadrupled from 4,339 MW to 17,405 MW, of which 5,783 MW was generated by independent 
power  producers  (IPP).  Thermal  power  plants  contributed  70%  of  the  increase,  hydroelectric 
power plants 27.5%, and nuclear power plants, 2.5%. 
 
Following  the  passing  of  the  Electric  Power  Act  of  1997,  the  power  sector  was 
13. 
unbundled  from  WAPDA.  Under  business  transfer  agreements,  most  assets  have  been 
transferred to new companies. Initially the shares of the companies were held by WAPDA. To 
increase the independence of the companies these shares are now in the name of the President 
of Pakistan. The voting rights of the shares and the nomination rights for the board members of 
the companies have been delegated to the Chairman of the Pakistan Electric Power Company 
(PEPCO), in accordance with a presidential directive.  
 

d. 

Pakistan Electric Power Company  

14. 
PEPCO  was  established  in  1998  following  the  Government’s  decision  to  amend  its 
strategic privatization plan. PEPCO has been entrusted with the task of managing the transition 
of  WAPDA  from  a  monopolistic  structure  to  a  corporate,  commercially  viable  and  productive 
entity.  This  has  involved  (i)  deregulation  of  the  power  sector,  (ii)  promotion  of  IPPs,  (iii) 
restructuring of WAPDA, and (iv) privatization of select corporate entities.  
 
Policy on WAPDA was amended because (i) despite the increase in generation capacity 
15. 
unmet  demand  still  existed;  and  (ii)  WAPDA's  growth  had  caused  inefficiencies,  “demand 
suppression”,  a  high-tariff  policy,  and  theft  of  power.  All  these  factors  had  adversely  affected 
WAPDA's financial condition. 
 
16.  WAPDA's  functions  under  its  water  and  power  wings  were  to  be  segregated.  It  was 
previously envisaged that all power generation, hydro as well as thermal, would be corporatized. 
However, it has now been decided that hydro generation should remain part of the water wing of 
the remaining WAPDA. 
 

e. 

National Transmission and Despatch Company 

The National Transmission and Despatch Company (NTDC) is a public limited company 
17. 
incorporated  in  Pakistan  in  November  1998.  It  began  commercial  operations  in  March  1999. 
NTDC was granted a transmission license on 31 December 2002 by NEPRA to engage as the 
exclusive transmission company for Pakistan for a term of 30 years, pursuant to section 17 of 
the Electric Power Act of 1997. Under this license, NTDC will undertake three specific functions: 
(i)  high-voltage  transmission  of  power  (220  kV  and  above),  (ii)  the  dispatch  of  all  power 
generation linked to the national grid, and (iii) the single purchaser and seller of power.  
 
As the sole transmission company  in Pakistan, NTDC is responsible for (i) maintaining 
18. 
and  upgrading  the  current  system;  (ii)  planning,  designing,  and  implementing  system 
expansions;  and  (iii)  operating 
to  system 
requirements  and  transmission  license  conditions.  The  company  took  over  properties,  rights, 
assets, obligations, and liabilities of 220 kV and 500 kV grid stations and transmission lines and 
networks owned by WAPDA under a business transfer agreement dated 1 March 1999.   
 
19.  MOWP has determined that the single-buyer function licensed to NTDC will be handled 
by  an  independent  agency,  the  Central  Power  Purchasing  Agency  (CPPA).  This  function  is 
being transferred from NTDC. A new license will have to be issued to NTDC and possibly the 
CPPA. As an interim measure, CPPA will be managed separately within NTDC. WAPDA Private 

the  system  dispatch  generation  according

31 

Power  Organization  (WPPO)  will  be  restructured  to  take  on  the  task  of  the  CPPA.  Terms  of 
reference  for  the  management  of  the  independent  CPPA  have  been  drafted.  ADB  has  been 
requested to provide technical assistance for the establishment and start of operations of CPPA.  
 

f. 

Private Sector Participation 

20. 
The  Government  appreciates  the  need  for  private  sector  participation  in  the  power 
sector.  In  2002,  it  set  out  policy  for  power  generation  projects,  which  provided  a  clear  set  of 
incentives, along with a regulatory regime. This effectively created a framework to attract private 
capital.  In  order  to  facilitate  private  sector  participation  in  power  generation,  transmission 
systems  must  be  stable  and  reliable  and  new  investments  must  be  made  to  respond  to  the 
additional  generated  capacity.  Pakistan  has  been  successful  in  attracting  private  sector 
investment  and  is  working  to  further  improve  the  enabling  environment.2  Independent  power 
producers account for about 30% of electricity generating capacity. 
 
21. 
The Government established the Private Power Infrastructure Board (PPIB) in 1994. The 
PPIB  provides  a  “one-window”  facility  to  private  sector  investors  in  matters  concerning  the 
establishment  of  power  projects  and  related  infrastructure,  including  negotiation  of  the 
implementation  agreement.  The  PPIB  also  provides  support  to  the  power  purchaser  and  fuel 
supplier in negotiating power purchases and fuel or gas supply agreements, and in liaising with 
the  local  and  international  agencies  concerned.  With  Government  approval,  PPIB  is  also 
responsible for  formulating,  reviewing  and  updating  policies and  procedures  relating  to  private 
sector investments in the power sector. 
 
The  PPIB  has  facilitated  investments  of  over  $4  billion  from  the  commercial  sector.  All 
22. 
power  purchase  agreements  have  government  guarantees.  As  a  condition  for  private  sector 
investment  in  generation,  a  reliable  and  sustained  ability  to  evacuate  the  power  from  IPPs  as 
well as delivery of the power to the end users is necessary. The power transmission investment 
plan will remove potential bottlenecks and ensure the evacuation of power generated by IPPs 
and  new  public  power  generation  facilities.  A  number  of  new  IPP  projects  may  also  include 
transmission  components.  NTDC  will  actively  seek  commercial  investments  in  the  larger 
transmission projects.  
 
C. 

Sector Issues  

1. 

Key Opportunities and Challenges 

23. 
Pakistan is a net importer of energy. During FY2000-2005, it spent about $3.3 billion a 
year, equivalent to 22–25% of total imports, to import oil to meet its energy needs. In the first 9 
months of FY2006, Pakistan's oil imports amounted to $4.6 billion, and for the full year, the total 
is expected to exceed $6.0 billion. Oil importation places a heavy burden on foreign exchange 
reserves and recent increases in oil prices and price volatility complicate this problem. Most of 
imported  energy  is  for  electricity  generation.  Even  with  all  this  imported  energy,  there  is 
suppressed  demand  and  the  power  system  is  unable  to  respond  to  peak  demand  (partly 
because  of  lack  of  capacity  at  peak  summer  and  winter  periods).  The  winter  peak  demand  is

Cluster  of  Loans  and  Technical  Assistance  Grant  to  the  Islamic  Republic  of  Pakistan  for  Private  Participation  in 
Infrastructure Program. Manila. 

 

 
 

 

 32 

Appendix 2 

putting thermal plants under pressure as increases to thermal generation have been insufficient. 
About 45% of Pakistan’s population has no access to electricity from the national grid and uses 
kerosene, fuel wood, and other forms of bio-fuels for lighting, cooking, and heating. Pakistan’s 
per capita energy consumption is one of the lowest in the world. 
 
24. 
The electricity market has been characterized in recent years by marked changes in the 
primary energy sources used to produce electricity. In FY1995, hydropower still accounted for 
nearly  50%  of  electricity  generated  by  generation  companies,  but  by  2005  that  share  had 
dropped to 30%. Over the same period, the share of thermally generated electricity increased 
from 50% to 65%, the result of capacity additions since the early 1990s. 
 
25. 
Electricity  consumption  has  grown  steadily  in  recent  years.  From  1995  to  2005,  total 
consumption increased by more than 58%, from 35 to 55 terawatt hours (TWh) per year, with 
the domestic sector accounting for the largest proportion of consumption, followed by industry 
and then agriculture. The demand for electricity is forecast to continue to rise. 
 
To  meet  the  projected  increase  in  demand  of  around  10,000  MW  by  2010,  the 
26. 
Government  has  launched  a  large-scale  generation  expansion  program.  Nevertheless,  power 
shortages  are  anticipated.  To  minimize  future  supply  deficits,  Pakistan  has  adopted  a 
systematic development plan called “Vision 2025” that targets a long-term capacity increase of 
around 35,000 MW by 2025 (almost double the capacity in 2002). 
 
27. 
About  two  thirds  of  the  additional  power  (22,563  MW)  will  come  from  hydroelectric 
sources, while new gas-fired power plants will contribute 13% (4,680 MW), about the same as 
that  generated  by  coal-fired  power  plants  (4,350  MW).  New  nuclear  power  plants,  with  a  total 
installed  capacity  of  1,800  MW  (5%),  are  also  planned.  Finally,  it  is  intended  that  renewable 
sources  of  energy  will  account  for  more  than  4%  (1,500  MW)  of  the  overall  newly  installed 
capacity. The planned expansion will cost approximately $30 billion. 
 
28. 
Natural  gas-fired  plants  have  operated  almost  exclusively  on  domestic  resources,  as 
have most of Pakistan’s coal-fired power plants. However, this policy of reliance on indigenous 
resources is being reassessed in the light of increasing demands for electricity. 
 
29. 
Several board members and staff members hold concurrent positions on the boards of 
the unbundled entities. This is not ideal from the corporate governance stand point. Because of 
the  inherent  conflicts  of  interest  between  WAPDA,  distribution  companies,  generation 
companies, and NTDC, such concurrent memberships may make it difficult for board members 
to fulfill their fiduciary duty to act solely for the benefit of each entity. 
 

2. 

Financial Issues 

30. 
The  power  sector  needs  sustainable  tariff  arrangements  and  resolution  of  the 
receivables  from  distribution  companies  as  well  as  payments  to  generation  companies  for 
electricity  supplied.  NTDC  plays  a  central  role  between  the  generation  and  distribution 
companies but its single buyer function has made the company financially unsound. Most of the 
PRs14 billion in losses incurred by NTDC in 2005 was because of the single buyer function. The 
2005  accounts  for  NTDC  also  show  that  the  cost  of  electricity  owed  to  the  generation 
companies was PRs192 billion but sales were only PRs189 billion. This PRs3 billion loss plus 
the operation and financing cost make up the loss for the single buyer function. There are also 
outstanding  receivables  from  the  distribution  companies.  The  disparity  in  receivables  and 
payables are caused in part by the current tariff arrangement. Distribution companies have not 

 

  

Appendix 2 

33 

been  able  to  charge  cost  recovery  rates  where  as  generation  companies  and  IPPs  have  had 
cost  adjustments  for  their  tariffs.  The  tariff  determination  was  made  for  WAPDA  and  not  the 
distribution  companies.  The  deficit  amount  covered  by  the  Government  is  a  subsidy  to  the 
electricity consumers. Cost increases in the electricity generated by thermal plants because of 
increases in fuel prices, will strain Government finances unless the distribution tariff is increased 
to cost recovery levels.  
 
31. 
The  current  Government  relending  rate  to  NTDC  is  17%,  pursuant  to  a  government 
circular of 1996. The rate paid by NTDC for its commercial borrowing is currently about 12%. In 
1996 the commercial lending rate was over 20% and, considering the foreign exchange risk the 
Government  was  taking,  17%  seemed  to  be  justified.  However,  when  commercial  rates 
decreased,  the  Government’s  relending  rate  was  not  revised  so  as  to  instill  commercial 
discipline  in  state-owned  entities  by  forcing  them  to  borrow  from  the  market.  This  matter  is 
currently under review by the Ministry of Finance. 
 
D. 

Transmission Issues 

1. 

Key Opportunities and Challenges 

32. 
Pakistan’s power transmission system faces three major challenges: (i) the heavy power 
flow through the 500 kV system, (ii) a shortage of supply capacity for the 220 kV system, and 
(iii) high transmission losses. Hydropower plants are located mainly in the northern parts of the 
country and the thermal plants are primarily located in the south. There is a heavy power flow 
from north to south during summer when hydropower generation is high, and a heavy flow from 
south to north in winter when hydropower generation is low.  
 
33. 
According  to  Government  estimates,  electricity  demand  in  Pakistan  is  forecast  to  grow 
by at least 8% a year during 2005–2015. To meet this increasing demand, it is estimated that 
Pakistan would require an additional 2,000 MWs annually, which would need to be evacuated 
through  the  transmission  system.  Substantial  investments  are  required  to  strengthen  the 
transmission system to (i) urgently address current shortfalls and quality problems, (ii) evacuate 
power  generated  by  additional  power  plants,  and  (iii)  supply  electricity  to  meet  the  growing 
demand. 
 
34. 
The  mismatch  between  the  location  of  demand  and  the  source  of  supply  requires 
investments  in  the  primary  network.  Current  peak  energy  and  capacity  shortfalls  are  to  some 
extent the consequence of shortages and bottlenecks in the national network. Primary network 
constraints  cause  inefficiencies  at  the  consumers,  such  as  high  levels  of  un-served  energy  or 
investment  in  costly  self-  or  captive  generation,  at  a  significant  cost.  For  example,  the  export 
competitiveness of the textile sector is eroded by high electricity costs and unreliable supplies.  
 
35. 
Because of the weak grid infrastructure and substantial thefts of electricity, losses from 
the  ex-WAPDA  transmission  and  distribution  network  amounted  to  some  25%  in  2005.  Total 
transmission losses are 7.5%, including the secondary transmission system losses. The primary 
system losses are about 3.0%.  
 
36. 
High  growth  in  electricity  demand  in  Pakistan  is  clearly  putting  the  existing  power 
transmission  infrastructure  under  severe  stress.  There  is  a  clear  need  to  invest  in  additional 

 

 34 

Appendix 2 

primary  transmission  facilities.    The  Power  Transmission  Sector  Road  Map  for  2007–2016 
(Appendix  3)  is  a  comprehensive  plan  that  specifies  the  details  of  system  renovation  and 
expansion  and  makes  recommendations  on  how  a  reliable  and  high-quality  power  supply  can 
be  delivered  to  the  growing  number  of  industrial,  commercial,  agricultural,  and  domestic 
customers.  It  is  consistent  with  the  Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy,  which  aims  to 
increase  the  level  of  economic  activity.  It  has  the  following  intended  outcomes:  (i) a  more 
efficient power system; (ii) high-quality power supply through a more reliable and stable system; 
(iii) greater  geographic  coverage;  and  (iv)  more  availability  of  and  access  to  affordable 
electricity, by bringing hydroelectric and coal-fired thermal energy to load centers.  
 

2. 

Transmission System Overview 

The  currently  installed  generation  capacity  of  the  ex-WAPDA  companies  amounts  to 
37. 
17,405 MW. Available generation capacity is about 13,000 MW because (i) hydropower plants 
are  dependent  upon  reservoir  capacity  and  hence  rainfall,  reservoir  silting,  and  irrigation 
priorities; (ii) the generation portfolio is ageing and subject to rating limitations and maintenance 
requirements; and (iii) there are increased forced outage expectations.  
 
38. 
The  immediate  concern  is  the  capacity  of  the  transmission  network  to  evacuate  and 
transmit  the  present  available  generation  output  to  load  centers.  The  maximum  transmission 
system demand of 13,051 MW recorded in summer 2006 is believed to represent the system at 
full  capacity,  or  over  full  capacity  according  to  safety  and  sustainability  standards.  This  is  a 
constrained maximum demand that is based on the capacity of the transmission network. It has 
been  estimated  that  at  that  time  there  was  800  MW  of  unsatisfied  demand.  Sections  of  the 
transmission  network  are  known  to  be  running  periodically  above  rating  limits,  increasing  the 
risk of forced and lengthy transmission outages.  
 
39. 
The load shed at generation, primary transmission and secondary transmission level is 
estimated to be about 800 MW. This load shedding figure does not include the “load shed” due 
to under-frequency and low voltage. This seasonal generation gap between supply and demand 
at present and in the near future is presented in Table A2.3.

46. 
The  total  investment  requirement  for  NTDC  by  2016  is  estimated  at  $3.9  billion.  The 
urgent and immediate transmission system rehabilitation and augmentation plan for 2007–2011 
totals $915 million (32 transformers, 775 km of lines). Investments for 2012–2016 will mainly be 
to  facilitate  the  evacuation  from  new  generation  plants  as per  the  least-cost  power  generation 
plan. The transmission investment plan covers 62 transformers, 4,415 kilometers of lines, four 
SVCs,  and  20  new  grid  stations.  A  detailed  description  of  the  power  transmission  sector 
investment plan is provided in Appendix 3.

Appendix 3 

 
A. 

Rationale  

POWER TRANSMISSION SECTOR ROAD MAP AND INVESTMENT PLAN 

Pakistan’s power transmission system faces three major challenges: (i) the heavy power 
1. 
flow  through  the  500  kilovolt  (kV)  system,  (ii)  a  shortage  of  supply  capacity  for  the  220  kV 
system, and (iii) high transmission losses. Hydropower plants are located mainly in the northern 
parts of the country and the thermal plants are primarily located in the south. There is a heavy 
power  flow  from  north  to  south  during  summer  when  hydropower  generation  is  high,  and  a 
heavy  flow  from  south  to  north  in  winter  when  hydropower  generation  is  low.  The  mismatch 
between  the  location  of  demand  and  the  source  of  supply  is  creating  a  considerable  need  for 
primary  network  investments.  Current  peak  energy  and  capacity  shortfalls  are  to  some  extent 
the consequence of shortages and bottlenecks in the national network. 
 
2. 
The  Medium-Term  Development  Framework,  2005–2010  (MTDF)  spells  out  the 
Government’s energy sector strategy, including investments in power generation, transmission, 
and distribution. Based on the MTDF, the Government developed a long-term power generation 
plan. This identified the demand for increased generation capacity and addressed the size and 
timing  of  the  commissioning  of  the  new  plants.  The  overall  power  transmission  strategy  is  to 
ensure  that  the  electricity  from  the  new  power  generation  plants  is  evacuated  to  the  load 
centers.  
 
3. 
According to Government estimates, electricity demand in Pakistan is forecasted to grow 
by at least 8% a year during 2005–2015. To meet this increasing demand, it is estimated that 
Pakistan  will  require  an  additional  2,000  megawatts  (MWs)  annually,  which  will  need  to  be 
evacuated through the transmission system. Substantial investments will be need to strengthen 
the transmission system to (i) urgently address current shortfalls, (ii) evacuate power generated 
by additional power plants, and (iii) supply electricity to meet the growing demand. 
 
4. 
High  growth  in  electricity  demand  in  Pakistan  is  clearly  putting  the  existing  power 
transmission infrastructure under severe stress and there is a clear need to invest in additional 
primary  transmission  facilities.  This  power  transmission  sector  development  road  map  is  a 
comprehensive plan that specifies the details of system renovation and expansion based on the 
Government’s long-term power generation plan.  
 
B. 

Objective 

5. 
The objective of the road map is to show how the National Transmission and Despatch 
Company (NTDC) can deliver a reliable and high-quality power supply to the rising number of 
industrial,  commercial,  agricultural  and  domestic  customers. 
the 
Government’s  poverty  reduction  strategy  and  has  the  following  intended  outcomes:  (i)  a  more 
efficient power system; (ii) high-quality power supply through a more reliable and stable system; 
(iii) greater  geographic  coverage;  and  (iv)  greater  availability  of  and  access  to  affordable 
electricity,  by  bringing  hydroelectric  and  coal  fired  thermal  energy  to  load  centers.  The  Power 
Transmission Sector Road Map, 2007–2016, is in Table A3.1.

1. 
The  investment  program  support  component  under  tranche  1  of  the  multitranche 
financing facility (MFF) is for $10 million. It will focus on (i) subproject preparation, (ii) subproject 
implementation,  and  (iii)  subproject  monitoring  activities.  It  will  provide  resources  to  ensure 
subproject  preparatory  activities  linked  to  tranche  3  and  subsequent  tranches  can  be  carried 
out.  The  component  will  also  provide  funds  for  the  timely  implementation  of  the  approved 
subprojects,  as  well  as  providing  knowledge  transfer  to  the  employees  and  management  of 
the  preparation  and 
National  Transmission  and  Despatch  Company  (NTDC) 
implementation processes. The component will ensure that the subprojects are implemented in 
accordance with the approved specifications and in particular that the environmental and social 
safeguard  aspects  are  implemented  in  accordance  with  the  approved  plans,  through  the 
establishment of a monitoring function. 
 
2. 
NTDC’s  experience  in  all  technical  aspects  of  power  transmission  is  satisfactory. 
However,  training  in  modern  transmission  planning,  utility  management,  and  information 
communications  and  technology  is  needed.  The  investment  program  support  component  will 
strengthen  NTDC’s  (i)  planning,  (ii) design,  (iii)  project  management,  (iv)  operations,  and 
(iv) maintenance  activities.  Bilateral  exchange  programs  will  be  developed  with  foreign  power 
transmission companies to develop role models among current and potential managers.  
 
3. 
The subproject preparatory activities under the investment program support component 
will help NTDC to prepare the subprojects under tranche 3 and later. It will also provide funding 
in preparation for power evacuation from the proposed imported-coal-fired power station in the 
Karachi area. The objective of the component is to establish the resources and structures within 
NTDC  to  enable  it  to  carry  out  project  preparatory,  implementation,  and  monitoring  activities. 
Preparation  of  the  subprojects  will  include  a  feasibility  study  of  the  proposed  1,300-kilometer 
(km)  transmission  line  from  Karachi  to  Lahore,  based  on  the  proposed  imported-coal-fired 
power station in the Karachi area. NTDC asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to consider 
financing this subproject under the Investment Program.  ADB will review the feasibility report of 
the proposed project, after which it will indicate whether it is willing to finance it. ADB would be 
prepared  to  consider  financing  such  a  long  and  complex  transmission  line  project  outside  the 
Investment Program. 
 
4. 
In  order  to  achieve  the  objectives  of  this  component  successfully,  there  will  be  three 
work streams. The first work stream, preparatory activities, will focus on: (i) transmission sector 
planning;  (ii)  individual  subproject  identification;  (iii)  subproject  assessments  (technical, 
financial,  economic,  environmental,  and  social);  (iv)  detailed  design;  and  (v)  procurement 
document preparation and bid evaluation.  
 
The  second  work  stream,  implementation  of  the  subprojects,  will  focus  on:  (i)  program

FINANCING PLAN 

 
1. 
If the Government of Pakistan’s growth targets are to be met, it is projected that demand 
for  power  will  grow  by  10,000  megawatts  (MW)  by  2010.    Without  a  stable  and  reliable 
transmission  system,  any  additional  generated  power  will  not  be  evacuated  or  delivered  to 
customers.  The  total  investment  needs  for  the  next  10  years  are  estimated  to  be  $3.9  billion. 
The National Transmission and Despatch Company (NTDC) plans to fund 30% of this through 
self-generated funds and the rest through borrowing from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
and other financiers. The Government is actively looking for funding from the private sector and 
other  agencies,  but  other  financiers  have  not  been  confirmed.  ADB’s  proposed  multitranche 
financing  facility  (MFF)  will  act  as  the  anchor  for  the  investment  plan.  Financing  of  the 
immediate and urgent subprojects planned for tranches 1 and 2 will provide additional revenues 
for  NTDC  to  carry  out  the  large  investments  for  energy  evacuation  from  independent  power 
producers (IPPs) from tranche 3 onwards. The investment program support component, funded 
from  ADB’s  Asian  Development  Fund  (ADF)  resources,  will  assist  NTDC  to  structure  the 
subprojects so they can attract investment from commercial sources.

Appendix 9 

FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT OF THE POWER TRANSMISSION SECTOR 

Introduction 

 
A. 
 
Financial  management  of  National  Transmission  Despatch  Company  (NTDC)  was 
1. 
reviewed  and  found  to  be  adequate.    NTDC  has  the  ability  to  undertake  and  fulfill  fiduciary 
requirements  for  the  proposed  Investment  Program.  Financial  management  assessment 
questionnaires  and  field  interviews  were  used  to  review  the  present  standing  of  financial 
management.  Due  consideration  has  been  taken  into  account  of  the  fact  that  NTDC  is  in 
transition  from  being  a  part  of  Water  and  Power  Development  Authority  (WAPDA)  to  a  fully 
independent  corporate  entity.  Progress  on  strengthening  corporate  governance  and  financial 
management is under way. Available public financial management assessment diagnostic tools, 
such  as  the  World  Bank’s  comprehensive  country  financial  accountability  assessment 1  and 
public  expenditure  review2,  and  ADB  assistance  programs3  were  reviewed  to  assess  NTDC’s 
financial system.   
 

1. 

Corporate Structure 

2. 
The NTDC is a public limited company incorporated in Pakistan in November 1998 and 
commenced  commercial  operations  on  March  1999.  The  NTDC  was  granted  transmission 
license TL/01/2002 on 31 December 2002 by NEPRA to engage as the exclusive transmission 
company for a term of 30 years, pursuant to section 17 of the Electric Power Act of 1997. This 
30  years  license  calls  for  NTDC  to  undertake  three  specific  functions:  (i)  transmission 
operations of the high voltage lines (220 kV and above), (ii) the dispatch of all power generation 
linked to the national grid, and (iii) the single purchaser/seller of power.  
 
3. 
As the sole transmission company in Pakistan, NTDC is to (i) maintain and upgrade the 
current system, (ii) plan, design, and implement system expansions, and (iii) operate the system 
dispatch generation according to system requirements and transmission license conditions, for 
smooth  transmission  of  electricity  from  generation  companies  to  distribution  companies 
countrywide. The company took over properties, rights, assets obligations and liabilities of 220 
kV  and  500  kV  grid  stations  and  transmission  lines/  network  owned  by  WAPDA  under  the 
Business Transfer Agreement of 1 March 1999.  
 
4. 
The  Government  has  proposed  that  the  single  buyer  function  licensed  to  NTDC  be 
handled by an independent agency. Procedures are on–going for separation of this function and 
financial accounts from NTDC. A new license will have to be issued to NTDC and the Central 
Power  Purchasing  Agency  (CPPA).  Tariff  determinations  will  have  to  be  made  for  CPPA  and 
agreements with generation companies and independent power producers have been revised. 
As  an  interim  measure,  CPPA  will  be  managed  separately  within  NTDC.  A  part  of  WAPDA 
Private Power Organization will be restructured to take on the task of CPPA.  
 
B. 

Financial Management Issues and Mitigating Measures 

The financial sustainability of the power transmission sector is dependent on timely and 
5. 
accurate (i) submission of tariff applications by NTDC, (ii) execution of the tariff determination by 

                                                
 
1 Islamic Republic Of Pakistan, Country Financial Accountability Assessment, World Bank, December 2003 
2 Pakistan Public Expenditure Management, Strategic Issues and Reform Agenda, World Bank, January 2004 
3 Institutional Capacity Building Of The National Transmission and Despatch Company (NTDC) TA 4130 

 

  

 

Appendix 9       55   

 

National Electric Power Regulatory Authority (NEPRA), (iii) notification of the tariff determination 
by  the  Government,  and  (iv)  collection  of  payments  from  distribution  companies  to  NTDC  for 
transmission  charges.  As  for  corporate  issues,  NTDC  has  (v)  financial  and  (vi)  management 
independence issues that need to be remedied. 
 

1. 

Tariff Issue (i), (ii) and (iii) 

 
6. 
In  the  tariff  determination,  revenue  requirement  cover  general  establishment  and 
administrative expenses, insurance, repair & maintenance (1% gross fixed assets in operation), 
NEPRA  license  fee  (adjusted  for  inflation),  depreciation  (3.5%  of  average  gross  fixed  assets), 
debt servicing (11.71% weighted average cost of debt) and, corporate income taxe (35%) and 
return on equity self-financing for its capacity expansion program (12.75%) less other income.  
The latest tariff determination was in January 2006 for 2005-2006.  The application was made 
by NTDC on 30 May 2005.  Stakeholders were notified of the salient features in a newspaper 
advertisement  on  11  June  2005.  In  response  to  the  interventions  NEPRA  decided  to  hold  a 
hearing  on  22  August  and  issues  raised  by  the  stakeholders  were  addressed  by  NTDC. 
Determination  was  notified  on  6  January  2006.      This  tariff  will  remain  effective  until  the  next 
application by NTDC, determination by NEPRA and notification by government.   Two types of 
tariff are determined for transmission the fixed and variable use of systems charge.   
 
Although  NEPRA’s  determination  procedures  took  6  months,  considering  the  due 
7. 
process  involved  this  is  not  excessive.    The  quality  of  the  past  submissions  by  NTDC  seems 
adequate  upon  inspection  and  has  withstood  the  determination  process.  NTDC  is  taking 
measures  to  improve  the  timeliness  of  tariff  revision  petitions  to  NEPRA  however  the  next 
revision is not necessary until 2008. The level of tariff determined stands to logic and is at a cost 
recovery level with allowance for the investment.   
 

2. 

Financial independence (iv) and (v)  

 
8. 
The  unbundling  of  the  power  sector  has  been  on-going  since  1999.  To  achieve 
efficiencies  and  transparency  that  were  intended  through  unbundling,  financial  as  well  as 
management  independence  is  necessary.  NTDC  continues  to  be  financially  dependent  on 
WAPDA,  NTDC  currently  has  satisfactory  accounting  capacities  and  established  accredited 
external audit processes in accordance with international audit standards. In addition, NTDC is 
developing  sufficient  in  house  functions  and  systems  to  handle  payments,  billings,  and 
collections. Accordingly, these functions can safely be transferred from WAPDA to NTDC.       
 

3. 

Management Independence (vi) 

 
9. 
As  the  transition  period  is  concluding  and  NTDC  has  built  capacity  for  independence 
from  WAPDA,  the  corporate  governance  structure  of  its  Board  should  be  in  accordance  with 
best international practices. Currently, the Board consists of a Chairman, three members from 
the private sector, and three officials. The Board represents the interest of the sole owner, the 
Government.    The  nomination  of  the  board  members  is  made  by  Chairman  Pakistan  Electric 
Power Company (PEPCO) in accordance with a presidential directive.   The Chairman of NTDC 
and  another  Director  hold  concurrent  seats  in  WAPDA,  PEPCO  and  NTDC.    The  unbundling 
process  has  come  to  a  stage  where  the  same  individual  holding  multiple  board  of  directors’ 
positions  may  not  be  the  most  efficient  way  of  promoting  Government’s  power  sector  policy. 
With  the  independence  of  NTDC,  the  representatives  who  hold  seats  in  WAPDA  or  any  other 
company  that  holds  generation  assets  has  conflict  of  interest.    Persons  with  such  conflict  of 
interest may find it difficult to duly exercise their fiduciary duties and their oversight role.  

 

 56 

Appendix 9 

4. 

Other issues 

 
10. 
The  current  on-lending  rate  is  17%  pursuant  to  a  government  circular  of  1996 
concerning on-lending to autonomous state owned entities.  This rate is currently above the rate 
paid by NTDC for its commercial borrowing, around 12%.  Instead of a fixed rate, consideration 
should be given to benchmark the rates to the borrowing cost of the Government with premium 
charged  for  foreign  exchange  and  credit  risk  of  NTDC  (autonomous  government  entity). 
However, even with this rate, the projects under Tranche 1 are financially viable.  
 
11. 
NTDC  inherited  a  manual  accounting  system  from  WAPDA  and  which  is  being 
computerized  at  present.  The  Head  Office  has  been  computerized  and  the  branches  will  be 
computerized by the end of 2006.  The speed of computerization and training has been in line 
with the plan thus far.  Expectation is for the progress to be consistent with the current pace.  
 
12. 
The  internal  audit  function  currently  report  to  the  Chief  Executive  Officer  and  the 
procedures are based on those which they have inherited from WAPDA.  The Audit Committee 
which reports to the board was established last year and is chaired by an outside auditor with 
the  NTDC  Audit  Manager  as  the  Secretary.    Discussions  have  been  taking  place  in  this 
committee to establish NTDC’s own audit procedures and policies as an independent entity.   
 
C. 

Financial Performance 

13. 
The transmission business of NTDC (excluding CPPA) has been financially sound in the 
last 3 years.   Revenue from the transmission tariff was separated from CPPA only in 2005 and 
it is only during this year that the affect of CPPA on NTDC is visible. The tariff adjustment has 
allowed financing for operation, maintenance as well as a basis for their investment plan.   
 
D. 

Assumptions for Financial Projection 

14. 
Financial projections in terms of profit and loss account, balance sheet and cashflow, of 
the NTDC have been prepared for 10 years from 2006 through 2015. The projections are based 
on  the  assumption  that  CPPA  will  be  transferred  out  of  NTDC.  Domestic  inflation  is  projected 
using  domestic  cost  escalation  factors  for  2006–20154  published  by  the  Asian  Development 
Bank  and  international  inflation  forecasts  use  the  international  cost  escalation  factors  2006–
20155 published by the World Bank.

18. 
The financial management of NTDC is adequate to carry out the fiduciary duties of the 
proposed Investment Program. In terms of financial strength, for the counter party funds, NTDC 
remains  profitable  up  to  2015,  even  under  a  very  conservative  assumption  that  the  annual 
increase in the UoSC from 2008 is only by 7.3%. Return on equity is 10% in 2010 and 6% in 
2015. More importantly NTDC produces adequate cashflow to maintain its operations and meet 
its  debt  service  obligations.  The  debt  service  coverage  ratio  (DSRC)  stands  above  1.2  times 
from 2010 and the self financing ratio, is very satisfactory from 2010 onwards.  
 
19. 
In terms of management, measures are being taken to strengthen the independence and 
transparency  of  the  system.    These  steps  seem  adequate  and  appropriate  considering  the 
maturity  of  NTDC  in  the  unbundling  process. The  Investment  Program  Support  Component  of 
the Program will give additional assistance to hasten the process. 

 

  

 

 
A. 

Introduction 

SUMMARY OF ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

Appendix 10     59   

 

The proposed investment projects to be funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
1. 
are  part  of  Pakistan’s  integrated  generation  and  transmission  expansion  program,  and  an 
integral  component  of  the  transmission  system  development  plan  prepared  by  the  National 
Transmission  and  Despatch  Company  (NTDC)  using  least-cost  planning  principles.  The 
economic analysis is based on a time-slice approach to the transmission system development 
plan, since individual subprojects are not stand-alone investments and in some instances would 
not  yield  all  their  benefits  if  they  were  considered  in  isolation.  The  economic  internal  rate  of 
return  compares  the  annual  streams  of  economic  capital  and  operating  costs  against  benefits 
based on willingness to pay. All costs, benefits, and revenues are expressed in 2006 constant 
prices. The analysis period includes the construction period and 30 years of operation. Details 
of  the  assumptions  and  calculations  used  for  the  economic  analysis  are  presented  in 
Supplementary Appendix E. The economic analysis confirms that the Investment Program will 
ease  chronic  supply  shortages  in  the  country  and  help  meet  projected  growth  in  demand  for 
electric power. Demand forecasts and cost–benefit projections were prepared and analyzed and 
they indicated that the Investment Program is economically viable. 
 
B. 

Demand Analysis 

2. 
The  nationwide  power  demand  is  projected  to  grow  at  7.9%  during  2006–2010  and  to 
increase from 15,500 megawatts (MW) in FY 2006 to 21,500 MW in FY 200 (Table A10.1). To 
cope  with  the  growth  in  electricity  demand,  it  is  estimated  that  Pakistan  would  require  about 
2,000  additional  MW  newly  installed  capacity  to  be  added  annually.  The  additional  generated 
power  increase  would  need  to  be  evacuated  through  the  transmission  system  and  brought  to 
the consumers through the distribution systems.

NTDC  prepares  electricity  demand  forecasts  for  its  least-cost  planning  purposes.  The 
3. 
latest  forecast,  covering  a  period  from  FY2005  to  FY2025,  was  prepared  using  a  regression 
based approach. Historical data suggest that, between 1995 and 2005, system demand grew at 
3.1% p.a., but for the second half of this period, 2000–2005, the growth rate increased to 5.6% 
p.a..  In  FY2005,  the  demand  increased  by  8.6%.  The  relatively  low  growth  rates  experienced 
during the late 1990s gave rise to a degree of complacency and new system additions were not 
made. This period also saw some reduction in maintenance budgets, all of which resulted in a 
system that is now unable to meet the demand for electricity. The high economic growth rates of 
recent years have necessitated plans for accelerated and large investments in the power sector. 
For  the  purposes  of  the  least-cost  analysis,  NTDC’s  base  case  demand  and  energy  forecast 
were  considered.  The  forecasts  result  in  an  average  load  growth  of  8%  p.a.  over  the  20-year

The Government has embarked on an ambitious village electrification program as part of 
its poverty reduction policy. The number of villages electrified has increased sharply in the last 
few  years,  from  68,292  in  2000  to  90,467  in  2005,  adding  an  estimated  demand  of  about 
3,000 MW.  Rural  electrification  needs  new  grid  stations  to  be  built  and  therefore  requires

6. 
NTDC  system  is  stretched  and  this  is  expected  to  continue  in  the  near  future.  Further 
deterioration  in  system  performance  is  expected  over  the  next  4  years.  The  supply–demand 
balance analysis based on the medium-term NTDC forecast shows that, even when all ongoing 
and  committed  projects  are  included,  the  NTDC  system  will  continue  to  experience  capacity 
shortfalls in the near future. The system is unable to meet the demand. The maximum demand 
(at  NTDC  network)  recorded  in  2006  is  13,051  MW,  compared  with  an  installed  capacity  of 
17,405  MW  in  2005.  The  load  shed  at  generation,  primary  transmission  and  secondary 
transmission level is estimated at 800 MW.

C. 

Economic Analysis Calculations 

1. 

Least-Cost Review  

 

7. 
In  order  to  establish  that  the  project  provides  the  least-cost  option  (or  part  of  the  cost-
minimizing  expansion  plan),  various  load  flow  scenarios  were  undertaken.  The  transmission 
investments were confirmed to be an integral part of the least-cost power sector development 
program for Pakistan. 
 

2. 

Cost–Benefit Analysis 

8. 
The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) calculation was based on incremental cost 
and  benefit  streams  associated  with  each  tranche  of  investment.  Economic  performance  was 
evaluated  by  comparing  with-  and  without-project  scenarios.  Incremental  consumption  occurs 
because  of  the  extended  availability  of  lower-cost  grid-sourced  electricity.  Economic  benefits 
accrue to consumers and the economy as a result of the Investment Program.  
 
9. 
The  main  benefits  stem  from  (i)  removing  existing  bottlenecks  by  facilitating  efficient 
evacuation of power from existing power stations, (ii) improving efficiency reliability and system 
security,  (iii)  evacuating  power  from  additional  power  stations,  and  (iv)  reducing  losses.  The 

 

 62 

Appendix 10 

physical output—rehabilitated, augmented, and expanded transmission infrastructure—will add 
to existing supply (incremental benefit) and will substitute for alternative forms of energy supply. 
The  incremental  benefits  were  valued  for  each  category  of  customer,  using  customers’ 
willingness to pay for electricity. 
 

3. 

Calculation of Willingness to Pay 

10. 
The  value  of  each  unit  of  electricity  to  customers  was  estimated  by  comparing  current 
prices  against  the  price  of  alternative  sources  of  electricity.  Particular  consumer  classes  were 
assumed to be willing to pay the difference between the present cost for an alternative source of 
electricity  and  the  amount  charged  for  incremental  grid-supplied  units.  This  was  used  as  the 
basis  for  the  willingness  to  pay  calculation.  The  analysis  identified  four  classes  of  electricity 
consumer: agricultural, residential, commercial, and industrial. The focus is on the main energy 
use  (and  the  alternative  source),  rather  than  on  the  full  range  of  appliances  used  by  the 
customer category to calculate the real value for lost load. Table A10.4 shows the willingness to 
pay and price of alternative energy for each consumer category.

4. 

Results 

11. 
The  economic  cost–benefit  analysis  results  in  an  EIRR  of  24%  for  the  Investment 
Program.  The  net  benefits  of  the  Investment  Program  were  estimated  to  be  $3.7  billion.  The 
sensitivity  analyses  show  that  the  Investment  Program  remains  justified  even  if  various  risks 
materialize.  Tranches  3  and  4  are  sensitive  to  reductions  in  demand,  but  this  is  considered  a 
relatively small risk given Pakistan’s long history of unmet demand.

SUMMARY SOCIAL SAFEGUARDS 

The  Government  of  Pakistan  has  requested  $800  million  from  the  Asian  Development 
1. 
Bank  (ADB)  to  undertake  the  Power  Transmission  Enhancement  Investment  Program  (the 
Investment  Program).  The  Investment  Program,  to  be  financed  by  a  multitranche  financing 
facility (MFF), will target Punjab, Islamabad and North-West Frontier Province (NWFP) with, the 
National Transmission and Dispatch Company (NTDC) as the Executing Agency. The Program 
will be divided into tranches, each covering subprojects for the construction or improvement of 
transmission lines and grid stations. New transmission line or station construction will have land 
acquisition  and  resettlement  (LAR)  impacts.  This  appraisal  of  social  safeguards  includes  an 
appraisal of tranche 1, two subprojects of which have LAR: the Mardan–Line Bay extension and 
transmission line, and the new Bandala station and transmission line. Subprojects implemented 
in NWFP may have impacts on indigenous peoples (IP).

(vii) particular attention will be paid to households headed by women and to vulnerable groups, 
(viii) LAR will be conceived and executed as an integral part of the project and LAR budgets will 
be included in project costs, and (ix) compensation will be fully provided prior to ground leveling 
and  demolition.  The  LARF  also  covers  all  issues  relevant  to  LAR  and  contains  the  following

Poverty Analysis                                    

Proposed Classification: General intervention 

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Pakistan:  
Major interventions in the energy sector are designed to achieve economic progress through infrastructure 
development. Both physical investment support and sector reform are necessary so that the benefits from economic 
growth will accrue to the poor.  
 
By expanding transmission capacity, the proposed Investment Program is expected to result in quality and reliable 
delivery of services to consumers, particularly benefiting commercial, residential, and agricultural customers in the 
region.  
 
Poor and vulnerable consumers, including social utilities such as hospitals and schools, are often the hardest hit by 
inadequate power supply, load shedding, and poor power quality. They will benefit directly from the subprojects. Direct 
positive economic and social benefits will result from the Investment Program.  
 
A positive, direct impact on local labor is expected during implementation and an indirect impact will be due to the 
increased income-earning opportunities generated by increased access to electricity and job opportunities during 
construction. 
 
B. 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
Project preparatory technical assistance consultants have prepared a social impact assessment and a poverty impact 
assessment. A socioeconomic survey was undertaken to provide a basis for the assessments.  
 
Grid-sourced power will have productive use, as it will substitute for wood, kerosene, and candles, usually at lower 
costs. After the first 3 years of operations, total benefits will be in the range of $200,000–$250,000 added value 
through production or services. Approximately 250 persons will generate additional income for tranche 1 subprojects. 
 
Most poor people in Pakistan are wage labourers or are self-employed. Over 40% of them live close to the poverty line; 
this indicates that shocks, such as illness, death or drought, have the potential to drive large numbers into poverty. 
Most are landless and less likely to have access to a health clinic or to send their children to school than those with 
higher incomes. A disruption of their daily routine makes them more vulnerable than other groups as they do not have 
the resources to insure against such disruptions. 
 
The Investment Program is expected to create new full-time employment opportunities in civil works. Improved power 
supplies will induce light industrial and commercial activity, creating employment and improving the productivity and 
quality of outputs in manufacturing and agriculture sectors.   
 
C. 
Is there a stakeholder analysis? 
 
Is there a participation strategy? 
 
Stakeholder analysis has been undertaken. All stakeholders have been actively involved, in order to reduce the 
likelihood of grievances and to ensure that benefits are distributed fairly. In addition, for the selection of unskilled labor 
in the project area, the contractors will consult with local township labor officials, local village leaders and jirgas and will 
also ensure that labor is hired on a nondiscriminatory basis.

Strategy to Address Issues 

 
The proposed subprojects involve the construction of high-
voltage transmission lines and substations. Some land 
acquisition is required, although impacts on individual 
households will be limited. 

 
The subprojects identified so far will not have significant 
impacts on indigenous peoples. However, an indigenous 
peoples development framework was prepared to cover 
any impact that the subprojects, under future tranches, 
may have. 
 
 
Positive impacts are expected. The subprojects will require 
construction labor and will result in permanent employment 
for the operation and maintenance of project facilities. 

 
The subprojects are unlikely to result in increased prices of 
goods and services accessed by the poor.  

 
No other significant risks were identified.
